This specifies the minimum and maximum amount of the medication to be taken during a single administration.
Where no range is needed, sending the same value in both the low and the high is the preferred solution.
Enables the checking of administration compliance that could results in fill-too-soon/fill-too-late contraindications. Supports circumstances where the dose can vary. (e.g. 1-2 tablets)
DosageItem.DosageRange
Dosage
For intravenous and other such routes, this is the time period over which one dose is to be administered. The flow rate is determined by dividing the dose quantity by the Dosage rate.
Required for intravenous administration
This is a modifier for a specific dosage line or for the entire SIG. Examples are: On empty stomach, At breakfast, before bedtime, etc.
Adds further constraint or flexibility to the primary administration instruction.
- moodCode must be DEFN for drug definitions (such as as monographs) - moodCode must be RQO for orders; - moodCode must be EVN for dispenses and recording of other medications { x.; }
Indicates the context of the administration.
moodCode = RQO, for administration instruction on orders
moodCode = EVN, for administration instruction on dispenses
moodCode = DEF, for administration instruction on medication definition documents/references (typically, monographs).
Puts the class in context, and is therefore mandatory.
A free form textual description of extended instruction regarding the administration of the drug.
Allows for expression of non-codable qualifiers such as: 'on an empty stomach', 'add water' etc; which do not affect calculations of frequencies or quantity.
This attribute is marked as 'mandatory' as it is the only information that can be specified here.
Indicates condition(s) that must be satisfied for the dosage instruction conveyed by a dosage line to be carried out.
The presence of this association indicates that the dosage line is "PRN" (as needed). If no condition is specified, the detailed condition and target time attributes may be omitted.
Allows providers to specify administration constraints that are not frequency-related. . E.g. Take on waking, Take 1 hour before intercourse
Describes diagnosis-related indications
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Identifies the type of diagnosis
For SNOMED, the complete diagnosis appears here. For non-SNOMED this should be a fixed value of "DX".
Identifies this measurement as a type of diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. It is set to CD because SNOMED codes may require post-coordination
A free form description augmenting the specified diagnosis code.
Provides greater flexibility in specifying indication.
A coded form of the diagnosis that is the reason for the current action.
Allows cross-checking the use of a therapy against its indication. Also allows analysis of best practices, etc. This attribute is optional because it is not used by SNOMED.
Describes symptom-related indications
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Code must be fixed to SYMPT if not using SNOMED
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Identifies the category of symptom being communicated.
For SNOMED, this will communicate the full symptom. For non-SNOMED this will be a fixed value of SYMPT
Indicates that this observation is expressing a symptom, and is therefore mandatory. It is set to CD because SNOMED codes may require post-coordination
A free form description to augment the specified symptom.
Provides greater flexibility in specifying indication.
A coded representation of the symptom that is the reason for the current therapy.
Allows cross-checking the use of a therapy against its indication. Also allows analysis of best practices, etc. The attribute is optional because it is not used for SNOMED.
Describes indications that are not diagnosis or symptom-related (e.g. contrast agents)
Allows separation of conditions from symptoms from other forms of indication.
Must have at least one of code or text
A code indicating some other action which is the reason for a therapy.
Allows for coded representation of a non-condition based indication such as administration of a contrast agent for a lab test.
A textual description of an indication not meant to be either diagnosis or symptom.
Provides ability to describe indication without labeling it a diagnosis or symptom. Attribute as free form text is the only information allowed.
References an existing event record by identifier.
As a request, refers to the event to be acted upon or which has been acted upon.
As a response, may be used to indicate the identifier assigned to a created object.
The identifier assigned by the central system (EHR) to the Event record being referred to.
Allows the event record to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the Patient whose event is being acted upon.
Ensures that the event to be acted upon pertains to the right patient.
This relationship is mandatory because the Patient must first be identified before an action can be taken on any event pertaining to the Patient.
References an existing Request or Order record by identifier.
As a request message, refers to the order record to be acted upon or which has been acted upon.
As a response, may be used to indicate the identifier assigned to a created object.
The identifier assigned by the central system (EHR) to the Request or Order record being referred to.
Allows the order record to be uniquely referenced and is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the Patient whose order is being acted upon.
Ensures that the order to be acted upon pertains to the right patient.
This relationship is mandatory because the Patient must first be identified before an action can be taken on any order pertaining to the Patient.
Distinguishes different levels of location granularity. E.g. Campus, building, floor, ward, room, bed.
Used for searching, as well as for understanding what is meant by a particular location and is therefore mandatory.
An indication of whether a place has the capability to move from one location to another. Example: air and ground ambulances, mobile clinics.
Allows flagging that the location does not have a fixed physical location.
This element must always be known and is therefore mandatory.

Any location where health-related services may be provided. Note that a single physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles e.g. a Podiatry clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.

Provides location information which uniquely identifies where health services are provided. This includes details and other supporting information on locations e.g. name, address, organization and contact parties. Needed when looking up facilities to link to patient records. Also useful when trying to find facilities to meet particular patient needs, as well as looking up how to contact the location.
At least one of address or coordinate must be specified unless the place is mobile.

For example, a service delivery location may be either an incidental service delivery location (a place at which health-related services may be provided without prior designation or authorization such as a church or school) or a dedicated service delivery location (a place that is intended to house the provision of health-related services such as a clinic or hospital). Dedicated service delivery locations can be further characterized as either clinical or non-clinical.
A textual name for the place where the service is provided e.g. Ottawa General Hospital.

Provides a human-readable label for the location. The location name is not intended to be parsed or analyzed by when processing the record. (E.g. To determine if a location is a hospital, look at the location type, don't check the name for the word "hospital".)
Multiple repetitions are allowed to capture historical names
Identifies the physical address for this service delivery location, I.e. What is the geographic location of the building.
For mobile service delivery location, this can either be set to the address of the "home" site for the mobile unit or can be set to a null flavor of N/A.
Allows location to be visited. May also be used for geographic profiling (e.g. a dispatcher may be looking for the closest hospital or ambulance that can help a patient in need of emergency care).

Because a physical address may not exist for mobile locations, and may not be expressible for non-dedicated locations such as water resevoirs, this element is only 'populated'. When no address exists, the null flavor should be set to NA.
Restricted to physical address only

Allowed status values are 'active' (the location is actively used to deliver healthcare-related services), 'suspended' (the location has temporarily ceased delivering healthcare-related services) and 'terminated' (the location has permanently ceased delivering healthcare-related services and may no longer physically exist.)
Identifies the position of the service delivery location according to a set of geographic coordinates.

Allows capturing of GPS, legal land, and/or range-meridian coordinates of a location for subsequent proximity searching. Also allows the capture of disaster sites and other non-dedicated service delivery locations which may not have a traditional address. (These locations are typically registered for public health purposes.)
Identifies the health region associated with the service delivery location (if any).

In Canada, many service delivery locations are organized into regions for administrative, coordination and/or funding reasons. Regions may influence where a patient may go for services. They may also be used for searching.
Because not all service delivery locations are associated with a region, this element is only 'populated' to allow null flavors such as 'NA'.
Administrative contacts within a location, allowing for communication with various departments or areas.
One of the most common reasons for looking up a service delivery location is to find contact information for the location.
At least one of addr or telecom must be supplied.
Identifies the general purpose for which this contact information is appropriate. E.g. Admitting, billing, after-hours, etc.
Helps the user to know which set of contact information should be used in a particular circumstance. This is a key differentiator of each contact point, and is therefore mandatory.
Provides a mailing address for the location
Used when communicating by post. Physical addresses may also be used for courier-type deliveries.
Information used to communicate with the location by phone, fax or e-mail.
Used for more immediate contact requirements
Identifies the various means by which the location may be contacted and the types of contacts that exist. Effectively acts as a mini-yellow pages or directory for the service delivery location.
Locations will frequently need to be reached to ask questions, schedule appointments, etc. They may also need to direct patients to reach the location.

This is handled as a separate component because many larger facilities have numerous functions. The contact information for emergency is not the same as the contact for admitting or the finance department.
Provides additional identifiers by which the location may be known.
In a registry, it is often necessary to link a location record to other registries or to commonly used jurisdictional identifiers.
An identifier by which the location is known.

Specifies the actual identifier that can be used for searching or linking. The attribute is mandatory because there is no point specifying an "Other Identifiers" class if you are not going to specify an identifier.
Specifies the kind of identifier being communicated. For example, billing identifier, regional identifier, public health identifier, etc.
Provides context around the appropriate use for the identifier and is therefore mandatory.
Describes additional identifiers for this service delivery location by which it may be queried or reported on.
Allows a source delivery location to be identified with more than one identifier for linking or historical purposes.
This is the name of the organization which issued and/or uses the identifier for the location.

Further qualifies how the identifier is intended to be used. For example distinguishing a health-region assigned identifier from a provincially-assigned identifier. Because it is important to understanding the identifier, the attribute is mandatory.
Identifies the major types of health-related services generally offered by the location.
Used when searching for service delivery locations of a particular type. Also provides more detail about what kind of service delivery location it is than can be expressed by the 'type'.
The organization responsible for the operations of the service delivery location.
To provide additional information regarding the management and administration of the service delivery location.
Unique identifier for the responsible organization.

The expectation is that these identifiers can be retrieved from jurisdictional provider registries. Where organization identifiers are not maintained in the registry, they may be omitted or alternative identifier sources may be used (e.g. identifiers issued by health regions).
Allows drilling down for additional information about the organization. May also be used as a query parameter.
The label by which the responsible organization is known and communicated with e.g. Capital Health District.
Provides a user-accessible label for the organization and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies component service delivery locations within the parent location. E.g. Buildings within a campus, wards within a building, etc.
Allows for drill-down as well as providing context about the capabilities of the parent service delivery locaiton.
Identifies a location of which this location is a part.
Allows a query response to return multiple levels of information when describing a location. For example "Emergency Ward at Good Health Hospital".
The recursion depth is restricted to 1 I.e. nesting only one level
Distinguishes different levels of location granularity. E.g. Campus, building, floor, ward, room, bed.
Used for searching, as well as for understanding what is meant by a particular location and is therefore mandatory.
An indication of whether a place has the capability to move from one location to another. Example: air and ground ambulances, mobile clinics.
Allows flagging that the location does not have a fixed physical location.
This element must always be known and is therefore mandatory.
A list of available services provided by the service delivery location.
Useful when searching for a location to provide a particular service. May be used to filter query responses.
Describes the kind of health-related service being offered.
This is the attribute that defines what the service is and is therefore mandatory.

Indicates the availability of the health-related service within the location (as known by the registry/repository). e.g. active (currently offered), suspended (may have been offered in the past and may again be offered in the future, but not available right now).
Services may not be always available; it is important to know whether a service is currently available when making decisions about where to send a patient.
Because not all jurisdictions will support capturing availability time, this element is being made optional.
Specifies the time that a specific service is generally available. E.g. 8am to 7pm, Monday through Friday.
Allows for a greater level of detail on service availability, i.e. hours of operation of a specific service at this location.
We'd like this to be String, but need a datatype change to make that possible.

Any location where health-related services may be provided. Note that a single physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles e.g. a Podiatry clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.

Provides location information which uniquely identifies where health services are provided. This includes details and other supporting information on locations e.g. name, address, organization and contact parties. Needed when looking up facilities to link to patient records. Also useful when trying to find facilities to meet particular patient needs, as well as looking up how to contact the location.
At least one of address or coordinate must be specified unless the place is mobile.

For example, a service delivery location may be either an incidental service delivery location (a place at which health-related services may be provided without prior designation or authorization such as a church or school) or a dedicated service delivery location (a place that is intended to house the provision of health-related services such as a clinic or hospital). Dedicated service delivery locations can be further characterized as either clinical or non-clinical.
A textual name for the place where the service is provided e.g. Ottawa General Hospital.

Provides a human-readable label for the location. The location name is not intended to be parsed or analyzed by when processing the record. (E.g. To determine if a location is a hospital, look at the location type, don't check the name for the word "hospital".)
Multiple repetitions are allowed to capture historical names
Identifies the physical address for this service delivery location, I.e. What is the geographic location of the building.
For mobile service delivery location, this can either be set to the address of the "home" site for the mobile unit or can be set to a null flavor of N/A.
Allows location to be visited. May also be used for geographic profiling (e.g. a dispatcher may be looking for the closest hospital or ambulance that can help a patient in need of emergency care).

Because a physical address may not exist for mobile locations, and may not be expressible for non-dedicated locations such as water resevoirs, this element is only 'populated'. When no address exists, the null flavor should be set to NA.
Restricted to physical address only

Allowed status values are 'active' (the location is actively used to deliver healthcare-related services), 'suspended' (the location has temporarily ceased delivering healthcare-related services) and 'terminated' (the location has permanently ceased delivering healthcare-related services and may no longer physically exist.)
Identifies service delivery locations contained within the described "parent" service delivery location.
Allows a more thorough understanding of the capabilities of the service delivery location, as well as drill-down to component parts.
Unique identifier for the contained service delivery location
Allows subsequent queries to drill down to detail information about this specific sub location and is therefore mandatory.
Describes the 'type' of component service delivery location. For example, a hospital might contain a laboratory or a community clinic.
Provides context about what the capabilities of the component service delivery location are. Allows for unique identification of a sub-location and is therefore mandatory.
A descriptive name for the sub-location.
Provides a human-readable label for the location and is therefore mandatory. In general, names of sub-locations will be unique within their containing location.
Identifies the physical type of the component location. For example, a campus may contain a building, a building may contain a ward, etc.
Provides context about the type of sub-location.
Used for searching, as well as for understanding what is meant by a particular sub-location and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the position of the service delivery location according to a set of geographic coordinates.

Allows capturing of GPS, legal land, and/or range-meridian coordinates of a location for subsequent proximity searching. Also allows the capture of disaster sites and other non-dedicated service delivery locations which may not have a traditional address. (These locations are typically registered for public health purposes.)
Identifies the health region associated with the service delivery location (if any).

In Canada, many service delivery locations are organized into regions for administrative, coordination and/or funding reasons. Regions may influence where a patient may go for services. They may also be used for searching.
Because not all service delivery locations are associated with a region, this element is only 'populated' to allow null flavors such as 'NA'.
If specified, filters the returned location records to those in the specified province/territory or municipality.
Allows filtering the physical location of the facility.
Filters the records retrieved to only include those which have been created or revised since the specified date and time. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Useful to retrieve information "since you last checked".
Filters the records retrieved to only include those records from a specific EHR repository. If unspecified, all "connected" EHR repositories will be searched.
Primarily intended to allow filtering an initial search to a local EHR repository for performance reasons.
If specified, filters the returned location records to either those which are mobile or non-mobile. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Allows restricting to either mobile or non-mobile locations.
Filters the returned location records to only include specific types of places such as facilities, departments, buildings, wards, etc.
Allows constraining the types of records to retrieve. Multiple repetitions are provided to allow more than one type to be included.

Filters the returned location records to only include locations that provide the specified type of service(s), etc. Multiple repetitions will be treated as "AND". I.e. Locations that provide A and B. If this criterion is used, it will only match on services that are marked as "available".
Allows searching for facilities able to deliver certain services or groups of services.
Filters the returned location records to only include those whose name includes the specified string. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Allows searching by name.
Note: Searches should be case-insensitive and should ignore punctuation and spacing. Some implementations may perform "sounds-like" searches.
Identifies an address that returned locations should be near to. Results will be filtered to those appearing within the specified radius from the identified address.
Allows retrieving facilities near to a particular location.
Identifies the various parameters that act as filters on the records to be retrieved.
Allows the user and/or the point-of-service application to constrain what EHR information they wish to retrieve.
Search Radius may only be specified if Near Address is specified
Filters the records retrieved to only include those associated with the specified protocols. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Allows retrieving records associated with a particular protocol. Useful in clinical studies and other research.
The element is optional because support for protocols is not deemed a neccesity for many healthcare providers.
Filters the set of records to be retrieved to only include those with the identified status(s). If no values are specified, no filter will be applied.
Allows constraining the status of records to be retrieved. Multiple repetitions are present to allow selection of multiple statuses with a single query.

Filters the type(s) or category(ies) of the records to be retrieved. The query will return both those records whose type exactly matches, as well as those whose types are subsets of the specified parameter. If no Types are specified, no restriction will be placed on the types to be returned.
Allows constraining the type of records to be retrieved. Multiple repetitions are present to allow selection of multiple types with a single query.
If specified, filters the returned location records to those which are part of the specified 'region'.
Allows restricting the retrieved locations to those associated with a particular health region.
If specified, filters the returned location records to those which are under the responsibility of the specified organization.
Allows returning all locations associated with a particular organization.
Identifies the distance from the "Near Address" within which locations should be retrieved.
Allows retrieving facilities near to a particular location.
Identifies the various parameters that act as filters on the records to be retrieved.
Allows the user and/or the point-of-service application to constrain what EHR information they wish to retrieve.
Search Radius may only be specified if Near Address is specified
Filters the records retrieved to only include those associated with the specified protocols. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Allows retrieving records associated with a particular protocol. Useful in clinical studies and other research.
The element is optional because support for protocols is not deemed a neccesity for many healthcare providers.
A globally unique identifier assigned by the EHR to the record (or records) to be retrieved.
Specifically identifies the record to be returned.
Because the primary purpose of the query is to retrieve identified records, the element is mandatory.
Multiple repetitions are allowed to support multiple detail records as part of one query for efficiency reasons.
The Organization responsible for issuing the Other ID identified in the OtherIDs Role Class
Supports the requirement to supply additional information regarding the assigning Organization of the OtherID
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents.
Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization

Due to the extremely large number of potential values for a code set representing all physical things in the universe, the class code indicates both the subtype branch of the Entity hierarchy used as well as a high level classifier to represent the instance of Entity. This can be used to constrain the eligible value domains for the Entity.code attribute.
An HL7 defined value representing whether the Entity represents a kind-of or a specific instance.
Examples: 1 human being (an instance), 3 syringes (quantified kind) or the population of Indianapolis (kind of group)

An Entity may at times represent information concerning a specific instance (the most common), a quantifiable group with common characteristics or a general type of Entity. This code distinguishes these different representations.
Unique identifier for the organization that assigned the non-healthcare identifier for the client.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the organization assigning the identifier to the client
A name for the non-healthcare organization
Populated attribute supports the identification of the organization assigning the identifier to the client

The IdentifiedEntity class is the entry point to the R-MIM and contains one or more identifiers (for example an "internal" id used only by computer systems and an "external" id for display to users) for the Person in the Client Registry. The statusCode is set to "active". The beginning of the effectiveTime is when the record was added to the registry.
Provides the message entry point required to add a person to the Client Registry
A code specifying the major category of the Identified Entity Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/RoleClass.htm
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
This identification attribute supports capture of a healthcare identifier specific to the client. This identifier may be assigned jurisdictionally or by care facility.
At least 1 client identifier must be present in the message
Populated attribute supports unique identification of the client.
Indicates the status of the Client role (e.g. Active)
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Indicates the effective time of the Client role;
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
A code that controls the disclosure of information about this client record.

Data in the EHR may at some point (and in some jurisdictions) be accessed directly by patients. Some health information may be deemed inappropriate for direct access by patients and requires interpretation by a clinician (e.g. prescription of placebos, analysis of certain psychiatric conditions, etc) Even where direct access by patient is not provided, there may need to be guidance to other providers viewing the record where care should be used in disclosing information to the patient. Non-clinical data (e.g. demographics) may need to be flagged as not for disclosure to patient and or next of kin. There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.
Populated attribute supports the business requirement to provide restricted access where required
Information about what language(s) should be used to communicate with the focal person can be sent in the LanguageCommunication class.
Supports the business requirement to identify languages used by client for the purposes of communication
A code indicating the language of communication
Mandatory attribute conveying the expected language message elements are to be transmitted in.
Indicates the preferred language for all communications.
Required attribute that supports the business requirement to indicate the preferred language for all communications.
Identifiers used for the focal person by other organizations are sent in the OtherIDs class. The other organization can be sent in the E_Organization Entity Class
Provides the ability to capture additional client identifiers that are not healthcare specific
A code specifying the major category of a Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/RoleClass.htm
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
Other non-healthcare identifiers for the Client (e.g. Passport, SIN, DND, DIAND, Drivers License)
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the client
A pan Canadian code further specifying the kind of Role such as Drivers License, RCMP, DND, Social Insurance Number
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client

The Parent Person class can send the person that is legally responsible for the care and management of the focal person. If the relationship (e.g., parent, spouse, unrelated friend) of the guardian to the focal person is of interest then a PersonalRelationship with the same persons as player and scoper should also be sent.
Supports the business requirement to capture identification and demographic information regarding the Identified Client's Next of Kin
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents.
Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityClass.htm

Due to the extremely large number of potential values for a code set representing all physical things in the universe, the class code indicates both the subtype branch of the Entity hierarchy used as well as a high level classifier to represent the instance of Entity. This can be used to constrain the eligible value domains for the Entity.code attribute.

An HL7 defined value representing whether the Entity represents a kind-of or a specific instance. Examples: 1 human being (an instance), 3 syringes (quantified kind) or the population of Indianapolis (kind of group
http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityDeterminer.htm

An Entity may at times represent information concerning a specific instance (the most common), a quantifiable group with common characteristics or a general type of Entity. This code distinguishes these different representations.
A unique identifier for the next of kin
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the next of kin
A name for the next of kin
Required attribute supports the identification of the next of kin
The Person class contains identifying and demographic data elements for the focal person similar to those in the HL7 v2.x PID segment such as name, gender, date of birth, deceased indicator and time.
Provides additional demographic data elements for the focal class IdentifiedEntity
In addition to IdentifiedEntity.ID two of the following three attributes must be provided to add a client Person.name, Person.administrativeGenderCode, and/or Person.birthTime
An HL7 defined value representing the class or category that the Entity instance represents. Examples: Person, Animal, Chemical Substance, Group, Organization

http://www.hl7.org/v3ballot/html/infrastructure/vocabulary/EntityDeterminer.htm

Name(s) for the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Provides information about telecom
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
Gender of the Client, this is not to be confused with Clinical Gender of a client. Administrative Gender is typically restricted to Male (M), Female (F) or Undifferentiated (U)
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
Date of birth of the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client
An indication that the client is deceased.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
The date and time that a client's death occurred
Required attribute supports verification of death from official source such as Vital Statistics.
Deceased time only present if deceasedInd is = TRUE
An indication as to whether the client is part of a multiple birth.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
The order in which this client was born if part of a multiple birth.
Required attribute supports the identification of the client
Address(es) of the Client
Populated attribute supports the identification of the client

Associations between persons in the Person Registry, such as spouse or parent, can be sent in a PersonalRelationship class. The exact nature of a association is described by the code attribute with a value drawn from the PersonalRelationshipRoleType domain. Most associations can be represented in either of two ways depending on who is the player and who is the scoper. For example, the association between a father and his daughter can be represented by a code of "father" where the parent is the player and the child is the scoper, or by a code of "daughter" where the child is the player and the parent is the scoper.
Supports the business requirement to capture additional information about the Identified Client's Next of Kin
A code specifying the major category of a Role as defined by HL7 vocabulary.

Links two people in a personal relationship. The character of the relationship must be defined by a PersonalRelationshipRoleType code. The player and scoper are determined by PersonalRelationshipRoleType code as well.
Provides a means to identify Roles played by entities
A code further specifying the kind of Role such as Mother, Father, Natural Parent or Step Parent
Mandatory attribute that supports understanding the relationship between the client and the ParentClient
The Organization responsible for issuing the Other ID identified in the OtherIDs Role Class
Supports the requirement to supply additional information regarding the assigning Organization of the OtherID

There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.

Associations between persons in the Person Registry, such as spouse or parent, can be sent in a PersonalRelationship class. The exact nature of a association is described by the code attribute with a value drawn from the PersonalRelationshipRoleType domain. Most associations can be represented in either of two ways depending on who is the player and who is the scoper. For example, the association between a father and his daughter can be represented by a code of "father" where the parent is the player and the child is the scoper, or by a code of "daughter" where the child is the player and the parent is the scoper.

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

documentation.businessName: Act Definition or Event Name Effective Time
documentation.annotation: Effective Time with regard to the act involved
Required attribute indicating effective time of this act

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. This includes an identifier for the role, mailing address, phone number, and the time within which the role is played (may be open ended). The scoping organization, which may be omitted if not needed, provides the organizational context for the entity that actually plays the role. For example, the role scoper will normally be the party that assigns the identifier for the role.

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided
A unique identifier for the service delivery location.

A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

documentation.businessName: Act Definition or Event Name Effective Time
documentation.annotation: Effective Time with regard to the act involved
Required attribute indicating effective time of this act

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. This includes an identifier for the role, mailing address, phone number, and the time within which the role is played (may be open ended). The scooping organization, which may be omitted if not needed, provides the organizational context for the entity that actually plays the role. For example, the role scoper will normally be the party that assigns the identifier for the role.
Roleclass required to provide additional information for the person responsible for providing healthcare services within a specific healthcare setting

Data in the EHR may at some point (and in some jurisdictions) be accessed directly by patients. Some health information may be deemed inappropriate for direct access by patients and requires interpretation by a clinician (e.g. prescription of placebos, analysis of certain psychiatric conditions, etc) Even where direct access by patient is not provided, there may need to be guidance to other providers viewing the record where care should be used in disclosing information to the patient. Non-clinical data (e.g. demographics) may need to be flagged as not for disclosure to patient and or next of kin. There may be professional policy and or legislative guidelines about when/if records may be flagged as not for direct disclosure.
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
An act that is intended to result in new information about a subject. In this instance, regarding restrictions to practice for a specified healthcare provider.
Supports the business requirement to provide information about a healthcare provider where privileges have been restricted.
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges
The value identifying the specific privilege and/or restrictions on those privileges
Populated attribute supports the validation and identification of the healthcare provider and his/her given privileges

This role describes specific qualifications that may be held the provider as a result of training or experience, but having no legal force. Example: a medical degree or diploma. The current model does not include role attributes such as name, addr and telecom because there are no known use cases in this domain where this role is contactable.
Roleclass required to provide additional information for the person responsible for providing healthcare services
Unique identifier for the Expertise or Credential.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials
A code for the degree or educational rank that the credential specifies. May also apply to an Expertise type.
If Expertise or Credentials are included in the message, then Role Type Must Exist.
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials

documentation.businessName: Expertise or Credentials Role Effective Date
documentation.annotation: The effective date of the provider expertise or credentials in the healthcare provider role.
If Expertise or Credentials are included in the message, then Role Effective Date Must Exist
Mandatory attribute supports the identification of the healthcare provider credentials

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided
A unique identifier for the service delivery location.
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
The code identifying the specific service delivery location
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
The telecom for the specific service delivery location
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location
Effective date of the specific service delivery location
Required attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

This is an optional output control parameter. Sender indicates via coded values which class or class attributes in the response model are to be valued in the response. By site agreement codes can be based upon local object model, or alternatively, the classes and attributes from the query response model, as in the example below. Example: requestor wants provider identifier, name and service delivery location data returned so ResponseObject is valued as follows:
<ResponseObject><value code="HealthCareProvider.id"/></ResponseObject>
<ResponseObject><value code="PrincipalPerson.name"/></ResponseObject>
<ResponseObject><value code="ServiceDeliveryLocation"/></ResponseObject>

Utilized to support cases when a source or consumer (such as a Health Authority) wants only specific information about a given set of providers. For example, a HA might want to know all the Work Locations for a given provider type, and wouldn't want to receive all information. The type of information expected in the response is provided via the response object.
Supports the business request to be able to specify expected response to this query
Outlines the values expected to be received by this query
Populated attribute provides tremendous value in giving the organization issuing the query the flexibility to request particular items in the response.

The role class, assigned entity, captures the critical information of the provider playing the role of interest. A record of something that is being done, has been done, can be done, or is intended or requested to be done. Acts connect to Entities in their Roles through Participations and connect to other Acts through ActRelationships. Participations are the authors, performers and other responsible parties as well as subjects and beneficiaries (which includes tools and material used in the performance of the act, which are also subjects). The moodCode distinguishes between Acts that are meant as factual records, vs. records of intended or ordered services, and the other modalities in which act can appear.

Acts are the pivot of the RIM; all domain information and processes are represented primarily in Acts. Any profession or business, including healthcare, is primarily constituted of intentional and occasionally non-intentional actions, performed and recorded by responsible actors. An Act-instance is a record of such an action.

A role played by a place at which services may be provided. The RIM defines two specializations of service delivery location: 1. incidental service delivery location - A role played by a place at which health care services may be provided without prior designation or authorization and 2. dedicated service delivery location - A role played by a place that is intended to house the provision of services. Scoper is the Entity (typically Organization) that provides these services. This is not synonymous with "ownership". This can be further characterized by a role code of: A)DedicatedClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the clinical setting (e.g., cardiology clinic, primary care clinic, rehabilitation hospital, skilled nursing facility) in which care is delivered during an encounter or B)DedicatedNonClinicalLocationRoleType - A role of a place that further classifies the setting in which non-clinical services are delivered. A given physical place can play multiple service delivery location roles each with its own attributes. For example, a Podiatric clinic and Research clinic may meet on alternate days in the same physical location; each clinic uses its own mailing address and telephone number.
Roleclass required to support the identification of the physical location where healthcare services are provided
A unique identifier for the service delivery location.
Mandatory attribute supports the validation and identification of the service delivery location

Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.
Value should always be AUT
The time the person responsible for the query made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the time the query was actually performed.
The time a decision is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
There may be constraints on the usage of the reasonCode attribute in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
Queries cannot be retracted, so this event identifier does not need to be locally persisted.
Used for audit purposes and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Identifies why this specific query occurred.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Allows identifying the reason for accessing information via a query.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request than actually running the query. E.g. Physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.
This should only be specified if different from the author.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered into the EHR.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization. The association is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the content desired within a query.
Provides support for queries
initialQuantityCode must be populated if and only if initialQuantity is populated
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.
Identifies errors or warnings that were caused by the previous message or that are being managed as part of the current message.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed. Queries may raise errors related to data-access permissions, non-recognized identifiers, etc.
Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize this access or update.
May also be used to override access to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis. That is, this message can provide the same functionality as the Consent message.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR. (E.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange.)
Important to tracking permission and managing patient consent.
Indicates the person responsible for the event that caused this message.
Critical for auditing and for validating permissions and therefore mandatory.

The time the person responsible for the event made the decision for it to occur. This may be different than the time the change became effective. (E.g. If a provider decides today to put a prescription on hold starting next Tuesday, the time of creation would be today and the change effective period would be next Tuesday.)
This date can be back-dated.
The time a change is made is a critical piece of audit information and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates how the person who recorded the event became aware of it.. E.g. Verbal, written, fax, etc.
May have ramifications for the audit trail and reliability of the information.
Indicates the formal digital signature of the message content.
Digital signatures may be needed for authentication of message content. The attribute is marked as optional because it is not yet clear whether there is a use-case for this, or where it will be used.

This is a messaging artifact used by HL7 to allow the time, signiture and method to be captured when the author is not sent. This will happen in circumstances where the author information is sent as part of the authentication token.
Conveys an authentication token associated with the event.
The token may represent one or all of the following concepts: author, dataEnterer, responsibleParty, location and dataEntryLocation.
Conveys information related to the individuals and/or locations involved with the action in situations where the authentication happens on a one-time basis rather than on a per-message basis.
An authorization token expressed as a GUID.
The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
GUIDs are an effective way of conveying a temporary authentication token
An authentication token expressed as a non-GUID string.
The Authorization token may represent the concepts of author, data enterer, supervisor (responsible party), responsible location and/or data entry location.
Some systems may choose to use a hashcode or other approach to token construction.
Identifies the action that resulted in this message being sent.
There may be constraints on the usage of the effectiveTime and reasonCode attributes in the definition of the interaction or the trigger events which are conveyed with this wrapper.
Key to understanding what action a message represents.
A unique identifier for this particular event assigned by the system in which the event occurred.
Identifier needs to be persisted by receiving applications, except for queries (queries cannot be retracted or undone).
Allows the event to be referenced (for undos) and also indicates whether multiple interactions were caused by the same triggering event. Also used for audit purposes.
Identifies the trigger event that occurred.
This is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the meaning of the event.
Describes the status of the control act, which is always complete (it happened).
Required for completeness of specification.
Indicates the time the event (e.g. query, change, activation) should begin and occasionally when it should end.

The time an event becomes effective may differ from the time the event is recorded (i.e. it may be in the future or the past). For events such as 'suspend', an intended end date may also be indicated.
Identifies why this specific message interaction (e.g. query, activation request, modification request) occurred.
The domain associated with this attribute will vary for each interaction and will be noted as part of the interaction description.
Allows identifying a reason for a specific action, such as 'reason for hold' or 'reason for accessing information'.

Indicates the person responsible for entering the query into the system. Used when different from the person responsible for the request (author). For example, physician requests administrative assistant to print off a patient's medication profile.
This should only be specified if different from the author.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the location where the record of this event was entered.
This should only be specified if different from the location where the event was authored.
Indicates a potential location for written records, and may also be important for authentication purposes.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Indicates the service delivery location where the event occurred.
Indicates where paper records may be located, and may be important to determining authorization.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token.
Identifies the authentication token that references information about the people and/or places responsible for the event.
Some systems perform centralized authentication of providers and/or locations. The association is optional because not all systems will make use of a token-based authentication process.
Unique number for this particular query.
Needed to allow continuation of queries and linking of query requests and responses and therefore mandatory.
This allows the sender to indicate to the receiver that this query should follow an expedited processing flow.

Intended to convey the 'packaging' of query results. This attribute does not affect which rows are selected by the query, just the manner in which they are returned. For example, a batch file containing responses, a response message containing multiple payloads, or a stream of response messages (notifications) each identifying itself as a response to a query request.
The number of response item repetitions that should be included in the initial response.

If not specified, the default behavior is to return all repetitions. However the recipient of a query may always choose to limit the quantity returned to be less than the number requested. Regardless of the number specified here, the number of rows returned will never exceed the number of matching rows based on the query parameters.
There may be a very large number of matching rows. To manage communication bandwidth, a limited set may initially be returned with further data retrieved by using query continuations.
Defines the units associated with the magnitude of the maximum size limit of a query response that can be accepted by the requesting application.
Needed to quantify the types of records requested to be returned in the query.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action. The association is optional because in some jurisdictions, the supervisor may be conveyed by he authentication token.
Important for audit information and determining permissions.
The association is optional because in some jurisdictions this information will be conveyed as part of the authentication token
This is the list of clinical and business issues that have been detected and/or managed involving the current action.
Any trigger event can result in errors or may allow for errors to be overridden or managed.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).

Indicates when the query was performed. If not specified, the assumption is that the query was performed at the same time the message was constructed.
Sometimes messages may be constructed and sent at a significantly different time than the query was actually processed.
Indicates the reason for the response given
Usually used to indicate a reason why a query was unsuccessful or was not processed.
Describes the results of a particular query.
Links a query response to the query that invoked it, and provides information about the overall result-set (which may not have been completely returned as part of the response.)
The identifier of the query this response is related to.
A single query may involve multiple messages. (Multiple continuations.). This attribute links all messages related to the same query and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the overall result status of the query.
Indicates whether the query was successful and is therefore mandatory
The total number of matching rows found by the query. (This may differ from the number of rows actually returned.)
Indicates whether additional content exists that may need to be retrieved by query continuations and is therefore mandatory
The number of item repetitions returned in the current response.
Provides a quick overview of the number of items without having to go through and count the data and is therefore mandatory.
The number of item repetitions yet to be returned in the current response.
Provides a means of evaluating the magnitude of the result and is therefore mandatory.
Identifies the content desired within a query.
Provides support for queries

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
